items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for North Sea Coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued. The particular area of concern is Kilnsea. Some overtopping and spray is expected in the Southfield Farm area, Kilnsea as a result of a tidal surge between 7:45pm and 9:30pm on Thursday 23rd September. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Southfield Farm. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as overtopping waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Friday morning 24/09/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber Estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in place for this evenings tide (Thursday 23/09/21). The particular area of concern is Kilnsea Village. Some overtopping and spray is expected in the Kilnsea village area as a result of a tidal surge between 7:30pm and 9:30pm on Thursday 23rd September. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Kilnsea Village. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as overtopping waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Friday morning 24/09/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
